data.title: Bill Clinton helps unveil Hubert Humphrey memorial at Minnesota Capitol
data.meta_description: In 1948, an upstart young mayor from Minneapolis impressed and offended attendees at the Democratic National Convention with a landmark speech in favor of adding civil rights to the party platform. Enraged, 35 “Dixiecrat” Democrats walked out, but Hubert Humphrey stood his ground.Humphrey, a future senator, presidential candidate and vice president, would later become known […]
data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

In 1948, an upstart young mayor from Minneapolis impressed and offended attendees at the Democratic National Convention with a landmark speech in favor of adding civil rights to the party platform. Enraged, 35 “Dixiecrat” Democrats walked out, but Hubert Humphrey stood his ground.

Humphrey, a future senator, presidential candidate and vice president, would later become known as the “happy warrior,” a politician who could compromise and negotiate across political lines. But on key issues such as civil rights, he was resolute.

“There are those who say to you, we are rushing this issue of civil rights. I say we are 172 years late,” Humphrey bellowed to the convention crowd.

On Saturday, Aug. 4, former President Bill Clinton joined Humphrey’s sons Skip, Bob and Doug in unveiling a memorial statue of Humphrey before an audience of 1,000 on the Minnesota Capitol grounds. The 7-foot tall bronze statue sits near the intersection of John Ireland and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. boulevards.

“He believed that public service was a worthy endeavor,” Clinton told the audience. “He believed that his adversaries need not be his enemies. … Hubert Humphrey believed that our founding fathers were serious when they pledged their lives … to form a more perfect union.”

Speakers at the dedication service included Gov. Mark Dayton and former Gov. Arne Carlson, former Vice President Walter Mondale, and Sens. Amy Klobuchar and Al Franken. State Sen. Dick Cohen, DFL-St. Paul, served as master of ceremonies. Josie Johnson, the first African-American to serve on the University of Minnesota’s Board of Regents, also offered remarks.

Mondale called Humphrey the most influential political leader in Minnesota history.

Humphrey died in 1978, 14 years after engineering the victory of the landmark 1964 Civil Rights Act, which ended segregation and racial discrimination in public education and federally assisted programs. The act also chipped away at laws in the south aimed at marginalizing black voters through special voter-registration requirements, setting the stage for the Voting Rights Act and other important civil rights legislation.

To get the Civil Rights Act passed, Humphrey, who was then the Democratic minority whip in the U.S. Senate, reached out to Republican Minority Leader Everett Dirksen of Illinois and redrafted portions of the legislation to make it palatable across the aisle.

“He was convinced that racial segregation and Jim Crow was a stain on our democracy,” Klobuchar said.

Several speakers and audience members remarked that that level of bipartisanship has become fleeting in government.

Last month, Rep. Allen West, R-Florida, told audiences at a political town hall that he’s heard up to 80 House Democrats are members of the Communist Party. Without singling out West by name, Clinton told the audience on Saturday: “I didn’t think there were 80 Communists left in the Western Hemisphere outside Cuba.”

Clinton said Humphrey would be proud of Sen. John McCain, the former Republican presidential candidate from Arizona, for defending an aide to Clinton’s wife, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, against political attacks because of her Muslim faith. He did not identify Rep. Michele Bachmann, R-Minn., as the author of those statements.

Pointing to the examples of Pennsylvania and Texas, Clinton also criticized the recent wave of voter-ID laws, which are tightening voter-registration rules and requiring voters to obtain state-issued IDs to go to the polls.

Franken said Humphrey would have opposed the two constitutional amendments that will go before Minnesota voters in November; one would require state IDs at the polls and the other would define marriage as being solely between a man and a woman, effectively undermining any future attempts at legislating gay-marriage rights.

Planning for the Humphrey statue moved forward in fits and starts over nearly 20 years. Lawmakers first appropriated funds for the Capitol memorial in 1993, but public and private fundraising and logistics took longer than many had planned.

The statue was sculpted by the Chicago-based husband-and-wife team of Anna Koh-Varilla and Jeffrey Varilla, whose previous works include Martin Luther King, Jr. monuments in Austin, Texas and Roanoke, Virgina, as well as a Jack Nicklaus monument in Dublin, Ohio.

Frederick Melo can be reached at 651-228-2172. Follow him at twitter.com/FrederickMelo.

Originally Published: August 3, 2012 at 11:01 p.m.
